Since you don't understand the preheating, I'll break it down:
The lean amine must be cold when it comes into contact with the CO2 (otherwise it won't absorb it). The rich amine must be heated up to release the CO2. So, the two amines (rich and lean) pass through a heat exchanger where the newly lean amine (hot, coming out of the boiler) contacts the rich amine (cold, coming out of the stripper). This heats up the rich amine and cools down the lean amine, thus reducing needs for heating and cooling and, more importantly in a submarine (I would imagine), reducing the amount of equipment and space required.

22:27
Fluids (liquids and gases) will always move from a high pressure area to lower pressure areas. If you have two bottles connected by a valve, one is 20psi and the other is 10psi, fluids from the first bottle will move from the high pressure, to the low pressure until it balances at 15psi everywhere.

In this submarine's case, if the ocean is one bottle, and the sub is the other. They want the sub's side of the exchange to be at a higher pressure so the CO2 will be the one going into the ocean. If they didn't pressurize the CO2 before release, the ocean side if the exchange would have higher pressure and its fluid (salt water) would flow into the sub.

Another example of this is internal combustion engines. If you have a turbocharged race car set to hold 50psi of boost pressure, the fluid(air) in the cylinder is at 50psi before compression. When your fuel injectors open up to inject fuel, this exact same interaction is occurring. Fuel pressure is normally ~47psi, so air would flow into the injectors, starving the engine of fuel. In practice, fuel pressure regulators will receive a boost reference and automatically increase fuel pressure with boost to ensure fuel flows the correct way at a consistent and predictable flow rate.

I actually work for a company that makes several different specialty chemicals for military, medical, aerospace, and heavy industrial applications, and my very first job was to package up these exact oxygen candles. Some people here have the empty cans in their offices as flower vases! You may very well be igniting a candle that I actually had my hands on (the timing works out well, too!) I was only there for the very last step, so at most I just taped the igniter to the side and put it in a box. It was supposed to be a 1 week temp gig, and now I've been here almost 3 years and there's a possibility of me getting to know a bit more about them in the not too distant future. IDK how much else I can say, but I am very glad I finally get to see how these things actually get used!

(P.S. there's a non-zero chance we may also have some involvement with the CO2 scrubbers and some other things on that sub, too.)

The "pre-heating function" at 23:35 is used for regenerative heat exchange. The hot, lean MEA leaving the Boiler/Stripper goes through a heat exchange process with the cool, rich MEA entering the B/S. This serves both to pre-heat the rich MEA so the B/S needs to put less energy into it and to cooldown the lean MEA so it will have better CO2 absorption when it gets sprayed back into the absorber tower. Additionally, there's also a cooler for the lean MEA, which uses an outside source of cool water to further lower the temperature of the lean MEA.

Source: spent 4 1/2 years on an LA class submarine

Regarding the CO2 scrubbing system, the preheat he is referring to is the lean rich exchanger, where the lean amine leaving the stripper (which is hot) preheats the rich amine coming from the absorber, the lean amine then continues onward and into the absorber. While the rich amine is preheated (reducing boiler duty), the lean amine is also simultaneously cooled which is needed for better absorption.

How do nuke subs make oxygen? Simple high school chemistry class level stuff - electrolysis, by passing an electrical current through water it splits it into it's two constituent elements, hydrogen & oxygen. The hydrogen is dumped overboard as it's not needed. The oxygen is exploited to provide life support to the crew.

Non-nuclear powered hunter-killer subs use the same method but (in some classes of attack boats) also capitalized upon to provide power - such as the hydrogen fuel cells of the German Type 212 U-boats.

Actually, the primary way of getting breathable air is to ventilate the sub with fresh air, the stale air is forced out via over pressure of the sub. Then fresh air is brought in via the ventilation system. This is part of the normal routine that occurs every 12 hours. The co2 scrubbers can clean and recirculate the fresh air between routine cycles. The electrolysis system is affectionately known as the bomb and is extremely dangerous to operate and therefore isn’t, or at least it wasn’t on our boat. And we had under ice capability. Pure oxygen increases the risk of fire from any heat source. So what might normally just be something hot becomes something flammable when saturated with pure oxygen. The other by product is hydrogen which is extremely combustible! Ideally the gas go safely where they go and do what they do, but there is always the risk of a leak which could become hazardous before it’s detected. At the time I was aboard we were not allowed to be go to school to be trained to operate the automated electrolysis oxygen generator. It was a huge no no.

Not sure why this just popped up in my recommendations, but glad it did. I learned a few things here and it reminded me of my grandfather. He worked at the Mare Island Navy yard as an engineer. He was part of the team that developed the CO2 scrubber for the Nautilus back in the early 1950s. He attempted to explain how it worked to me when I was in about Jr. High (he died in 1977) but I didn't really get it. I'm not sure the system is really the same, but this was still a fascinating look at something that he was a part of the beginning of.

I also know why those burnt candles are called "clinkers". Grew up with a coal furnace and the burnt out coal produced a sort of glass-like foamy rock that "clinked" when you were shoveling it out. So the hard residue after something has had all the flammables burned out always seem to be called clinkers, even if they don't make that distinctive coal ash clink.

I rode a nuclear attack submarine (SSN 680) for four years.  I knew how we created oxygen, but never actually saw a candle until this video.  We did once have a fire in our TDU (Trash Disposal Unit) when someone irresponsibly disposed of dust from an oxygen candle.  No significant damage, but scary for a few moments for sure.  Now I did know we had CO2 scrubbers.  I also knew we had amine in the air and because of the smell, my wife always made me drop all of my clothes that had been onboard outside the door when I came home from sea.  But what I didn't know, was that the amine was used for the CO2 scrubbers.  So you just taught me some things I didn't know about how I survived aboard a nuclear submarine for four years.  I was what those machinists showing you around would call a "forward puke," so those kinds of things were not my responsibility or area of expertise.

Submariner veteran here. Interesting fact. We call the 0(2) generator the bomb. It utilizes extremely high voltage electricity to separate the oxygen and hydrogen molecules in water. It is essentially a very dangerous but well proven piece of equipment. We can also regulate the percentage of oxygen in the boats atmosphere. We normally keep it around 19 to 21%. In case of a fire on board we reduce it to 17% to make putting the fire out easier and reduce the risk of it spreading.
Gentlemen, truly, thank you for your service and God bless you.

At 23:36 Dustin said, "I don't really understand this part but dowl said there is a pre-heating function that happens before it moves over to the boiler stripper"
The answer to that is so rich MEA can preheat so when it goes to the boiler, it can start boiling straightaway. If we don't pre-heat the rich MEA liquid, it will go into the boiler and cool down the MEA in boiler stripper stopping the continuous boiling process.
Example: That's like if you are boiling water in a saucepan and if you add cold water in that saucepan, water stops boiling for a bit until the temperature of the liquid (water) rise up to the boiling temperature again. Compared to when you add hot water in a boiling water, it starts boiling pretty quickly and if you add boiling water in a boiling pot, it will continue to boil without interruption.
Please feel free to comment if anyone needs me to elaborate even more, hope you find this helpful.

A couple years ago my wife left some chlorine bleach in the toilet after she’d cleaned it and she forgot to come back and flush it a few minutes later. I went in the bathroom and I was standing up peeing and suddenly I saw my oee turn orange and it gave off a powerful gas that came up from the toilet. I had the difficult and uncomfortable task of stopping peeing mid stream and got the heck out of the bathroom after quickly flushing the toilet. I was shocked and couldn’t understand what just happened when my wife heard the commotion and realized she had forgot to flush it and I’d just peed in it. I researched it and found out we have ammonia in our urine and when mixed with chlorine bleach or the sodium hypochlorite that’s in it it creates a toxic gas called chloramine. I knew we had nitrogen in our urine but had no idea there is ammonia in it as well.
It causes great concern when you take a pee and you see your urine turn orange and give off toxic fumes :)

The lean MEA needs to be cooled before going back into the absorber vessel otherwise it wouldn't take in any CO2. That preheater is really an interchanger between the cold Rich MEA and the hot Lean MEA. Instead of heating/cooling the MEA streams independently, the interchanger moves the heat to where it needs to go in order to save energy.

A clinker is a term used in blacksmithing. You make cllinkers in coal/coke forges. They form at the base of the fire where fresh air is blown in and combine with iron oxides and other impurities in the solid fuel released during combustion. These byproducts  form a melt which comes together at the base of the fiie pot. The temperature here is less as fresh air is introduced from the bellows cooling the immediate environment. This melt turns solid and a clinker is formed. In geology a clincker refers to the sharp jagged solid crust of an A'A (thick) lava flow. These flows actually roll as they move like a tank tread the clickers being the outer layer in contact  with the ground or the tread in our tank analogy. Just beneath the clincker is a molten core of thick viscous lava. Thus concludes todays fun facts from your friendly blackemithing geologist.

The "oxygen candle" is actually a chlorate candle (not a regular one...). It is NaClO3. Once lit, it burns(!). Basically, no way of stopping it. It creates salt and oxygen in the process:
2 NaClO3 + exothermal reaction (flame) -> 2 NaCl + 3 O2. This is difficult to control though; you can calculate the overall oxygen, but once lit, you create it. And by that you risk creating too much oxygen, creating a toxic environment for human beings.

Can't we use MEA method in all our houses

23:37 About the "preheater": The submariner said heat exchanger.. In the stripper, the rich MEA has to be hot to release the CO₂, while in the absorber tower, the lean MEA should be cold to absorb as much CO₂ as possible. That means you have to cool down the MEA between the stripper and the absorber. The most efficient way of doing that is taking the heat out of the lean MEA between the stripper and the absorber, and putting it back into the rich MEA going from the absorber to the stripper.
Some domiciles use a similar approach to save on energy with showers. A heat exchanger can transfer heat from the used shower-water going down the drain into the water going into the boiler.
It's also used in HVAC¹ systems. When fresh air is pumped in to replace the stale air, a heat exchanger transfers heat between the new and old air, cooling or heating the new air as appropriate.

¹: Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning

@SmarterEveryDay Somebody probably posted this already but I can't find it, so here goes. 
I can say with quite a bit of certainty that the "preheating function" the Dow was talking about had something to do with a heat exchanger (there is a wikipedia article about heat exchangers). The lean MEA from the boiler-stripper is too hot to absorb any CO2, so it has to be cooled down. Conveniently, the rich MEA from the absorber tower needs to be heated up. So a heat exchanger will do both at the same time using the heat from the lean MEA. This means that less energy from the reactor is needed to facilitate this process. I hope this helps.

Subs take in water Di Hydrogen monOxide. Said compound then has its bonds broken. The Oxygen is then produced (this is for nuclear subs). Diesel subs have "scrubbers". Most diesel subs must surface to get new air.
The nuclear reactor causes the break-down of the bonds of Hydrogen and oxygen. Thus, the oxygen is released.

One must remember that in a pure oxygen environment, fires can break out rapidly. If I miss my guess, a space Apollo 01 (I think) used a pure oxygen environment. We must mix said pure oxygen with other elements.

One important thing to understand about nuclear powered vessels; you don't "plug" anything into the reactor itself, all it is there to do is generate heat.  The heat is used to create steam which operates turbines that drive the ship and generate electricity.  So, essentially, nuclear powered vessels are steamships that use reactor(s) instead of boilers.

I worked at an oil refinery.  We used MEA to scrub out hydrogen sulfide from the waste gasses that we supplement the refinery fuel gas system, or burns up at our flare if the fuel system is “long” on gas.  The rich mea is sent to our sulfur recovery plant.  At the  boil the mea to liberate the H2S, which is either sent through reactors (with catalyst) and converted to elemental sulfur, or to our sulfuric acid plant to regenerate H2SO4.  I believe the heat exchanger may be used on the sub to remove heat from the compressor, while preheating the mea.

You mentioned not understanding the heat exchanger, or preheater, on the amine unit.  While I don't know submarine systems, in natural gas processing installations, the hot amine that has been "boiled" to remove the acid gasses in the distillation column (lean amine), makes a pass through a heat exchanger that is exchanging heat with the incoming righ amine from the contact tower.  This "pre-heats" the amine before entering the "distillation column", thus requiring less energy to heat it, and also causes the hot lean amine to lose heat before returning to the contact tower.  I suspect there may be additional cooling of the lean amine before returning to the contact tower, or perhaps cooling of the scrubbed air, otherwise they would be blowing around hot air, unless the heat exchanger is extremely efficient an provides sufficient cooling of the lean amine.  Keep in mind also that the amine remains in liquid form in the still column and remains in the bottom.  Only the acid gasses flash off and  exit the top of the still. column.

MEA works so well for CO2 scrubbing because it is both alcohol and an amine. The amino group (-NH2) is basic and attracts the relatively acidic carbon dioxide (CO2) / carbonic acid (CO2 + H20 -> H2CO3), while the alcohol group (-OH) is polar and makes it more water-like and therefore more water-soluble.
Also higher pressure increased CO2 solubility, this follows Henry's law.

If you are curious, chlorate is actually produced by electrolysis of saturated chloride solution in a so called alkali chlorate cell. So the "candle" was also made by electrolysis, the oxygen is just chemically bound.

Chlorate can be also made by boiling bleach - here hypochlorite disproportionates into chloride and chlorate, though electrolysis is more efficient.

Well, reverse osmosis can be easily explained. It's just opposite to regular osmosis.
TL;DR - it works like a filter. Push stuff through and what can get through, it will get there, everything else will be left behind.
Long story - regular osmosis happens when you have two substances divided with some restrictive membrane and they try to equalize concentration of everything. Let's take a balloon. If you will that with air, it will be aired up for a long time. There is some exchange in molecules through the rubber but you have the same concentration in and out, so not much will change. Fill it with hydrogen and something else happens. On the one hand, hydrogen concentration is close to 100% inside and very low outside so it really wants to get out. On the other hand there is much less oxygen, nitrogen and other gases inside so they try to get in. Over the time some of hydrogen escapes and some of other gases get in. Your hydrogen concentration goes down as the balloon gradually let's other gasses in. Obviously hydrogen is smaller than other elements so it escapes faster than other ones get in and that's why it will shrink quite quickly. The opposite happens when you fill the balloon with sulfur hexafluoride. This one has quite big molecules. That's why it makes your voice quite deep. In this case it also tries to escape but is slower than oxygen or nitrogen trying to get in. This way the balloon will actually grow as it fills with other gasses. Even better example would be with pure and dirty water. Let's say you have a tank split with membrane. This membrane lets water pass through but will filter out stuff like salt. Now one side is filled with pure water, other side is filled with salt water. Now they want to equalize concentrations but the salt can't get through the membrane. The only way is to get this pure water from the one side to the other and that's what happens. In ocean salt water you have roughly 3,5% of salt which (assuming no other substances) leaves just 96,5% water. So 100% water from the other side tries to get in but no salt can get out. In theory all of the water would then try to get on the other side until nothing is left behind, that's the only way it could equalize. We have gravity though and the more water you have on the one side, the more it is trying to flow back through the membrane. At some point both movements equalize and you will be left with two sides on the tank filled to different level. The same way dehydration works. If you drink fluids rich in minerals, then they will equalize concentration moving to your body. If you drink distilled water, then this water will pull minerals from your body.
You've got the idea. So now you have the container with salt water on the one side and fresh on the other. Naturally osmosis pushes fresh water towards salt water to equalize concentrations. Now you can use a lot of force and push this water back through the membrane. This way you are increasing salt concentration by removing water on the one side and you are filling the other side with pure water. That's all it is. Reverse osmosis is quite fancy name for just very precise filter.

The MEA preheater is one side of a regenerative heat exchanger (RHX).  One side of the RHX has hot lean MEA and the other side has cool rich MEA.   The lean MEA needs to be cooled down so it will absorb the CO2.  So, the hot lean MEA is used to preheat the cool rich MEA before it goes into the boiler stripper, and this also cools the lean MEA.  If I remember correctly, there is another heat exchanger which uses cool water to further cool the lean MEA after it goes through the regenerative heat exchanger.  The regenerative heat exchanger reduces the amount of heat the electric heaters in the boiler/stripper need to add to raise temperature high enough to drive off the CO2.

I think the term 'clinker' for when the candle is completely spent, would be like when blacksmiths are using coal/coke for heating their steel. When all the carbon is used up for the heating, all that is left is chunks of impurities that do not burn off and are stuck down the bottom of the forge. it is a hard and brittle and needs to be removed as it will stop the air flow due to is clogging up the vent/grate at the bottom for air to come through. I suspect the 'clinker' on the submarine candles is similar, and is all the impurities and stuff that will not burn off.

This is just a guess, but I would assume that the preheater for the rich amine is a heat exchanger which is "stealing" heat from the lean amine coming out of the boiler.  Doing so would reduce how much electricity is needed by the boiler.  Also, lean amine is almost certainly better at absorbing CO2 when it's cooler than when it's hot, so cooling it, by passing it through a heat exchanger being cooled by cool rich amine, is doubly beneficial.

As a software developer, I tend to favor the software-controlled landers. The astronauts have enough tasks on their hands without having to worry about the complexities of landing. What if the software/hardware fails? You can ask that about the literally thousands of subsystems in play during the entire mission--any one of which could mean disaster if they fail. The answer lies in thorough testing and failover backup systems. Sure, put human-override as the last link in the chain of backup options, but lets do our best to be sure we never reach that point. Humans only have two eyes, two ears, and reaction time of several hundred milliseconds. Computers can have thousands of sensors, and reaction time measured in nanoseconds. And they don't get hungry, thirsty, tired, or distracted.

Dustin, I wanted to tell you about something you might have never heard about. Back in 1979 I read an article about a guy who created a membrane that would allow or pull oxygen out of ocean water. Its made of plastic with red blood cells mixed in with the plastic. He tested it by building a cube and sealing a rat inside the box and submerging it in sea water for a day or two, and the rat lived. I think the guy was a scientist in Israel, but I'm not sure of this. I think I read this in Popular Science. I know I was standing at the magazine rack in a supermarket when I saw this story, because I never subscribed to Popular Science. Then again it might have been in Scientific American. The article went on to say that the Navy was interested in his invention.
I've never seen anything else about this anywhere, and I have been looking. Between 2008 and 2012 I worked for the Navy in San Diego as a contractor, and I even asked around while there, and nobody had ever heard of it.
So I don't know if it was really a working thing. It could have been and it just went dark. I would love to know if it would really work.

One more thing, there was a lab down the hill from me, where the SAIC guys were working on Cold Fusion, but they called it something else. And they got results and it was posted on YouTube. Then they shut down the project. Our tax dollars at work.

Fun Fact: We are capable of scrubbing the CO2 out of this planet's atmosphere similarly to the way described in this video in amounts equal to or greater than what we produce. We have already built and used facilities to do such, with the largest currently being built in Texas. It is a 1 Megaton atmospheric CO2 plant, which is the equivalent of 14,000,000 trees in that one CO2 plant. It works great and we would only need 40,000 of those facilities across the world to capture all of the CO2 produced on Earth. Sadly all our anti-CO2 funding is going into monetarily inefficient "green ideas" hyped by the mainstream environmentalists funded by certain institutions focused on selfish goals which are not going to help the majority of our people prosper while keeping our environment healthy.

Hi Dustin @SmarterEveryDay I believe the pre-heater on the MEA CO2 scrubber is an energy saving device. When the CO2 is compressed it increases in temperature. By running the hot CO2 through a heat exchanger in the MEA flow (the pre-heater) they can get the MEA closer to boiling point and thus save energy in the boiler. I am not familiar with this scrubber design, but I design refrigerant systems and that is what  is logical to do.

On that pre-heating portion:

You want cool lean MEA in the scrubber and you want hot rich in the stripper. So you could either put a refrigerator or radiator behind the stripper and waste all the heat you put into the MEA or you can use a heat exchanger. With a heat exchanger you transfer the hear from the rich MEA you want to cool down into the lean MEA you want to heat up. This reduces the need to put additional energy into the system for heating and cooling.

23:37 The explanation is simple. The "amin" wants to be fizzy when it is cold but it wants to be flat when hot. So after the amin is saturated with CO2, it is heated up, which causes it to release that CO2. That is why the tower is called "boiling tower" because the CO2 is boiled out. This results in gaseous CO2 and the lean amin. The gaseous CO2 is pumped off by that compressor, the lean amin is cooled off and fed back to the absorption tower, where it completes the cycle.

the MEA is turned into a carbonate salt would be my guess.

they would probably preheat the carbonate salt to keep it liquid when they put it under pressure so they get
a smooth crack of the carbonate back to freebase amine.

many amines form carbonate salts that are mostly solid with often low melting points hence the need for preheating
so they can be pumped and pressurized.

when ethanolamine carbonate is heated to the right temp it will crack the salt allowing the carbon dioxide to leave.

this could be over the boiling point of ethanolamine hence the need for the pressure.

I would say the ethanolamine was there choice in the least toxic amine to use as some of the other options are not
too friendly :)

the great thing about using a base like an amine to capture CO2 is that it is a simple acid base reaction to
remove the amine from the breathable air that is expelled so I would say the scrubbers are just acid tanks.

many amines that are small like this one smell of ammonia in there freebase state but as a salt have a fishy smell,.
this fishy smell would be the smell that the sailors would be talking of I think.

So, to explain the pre-heating of the MEA, it is done by a heat exchanger. Think of it like a radiator, on one side you have the recently boiled Lean MEA, on the other you have the cold Rich MEA. The thermal energy is transferred across the heat exchanger, simultaneously cooling the Lean MEA and heating the Rich MEA. It's more efficient in several ways. 1) if you already have something hot nearby, why waste the energy heating it up if you can sap heat from something you want to cool. 2) cool MEA absorbs CO2 better, so you spend less energy cooling it before it is sent back to the absorbing tower.

To those wondering why you need to heat up the MEA. Any physicists among us thought : "Why is this not a perpetuum mobile ?"
The secret lies in the heating. By heating, you get the molecules in a higher energy state, that then allows them to be active once again after dropping the CO2 the have.
You put them in a configuration that isn't stable at a lower temperature with the CO2, so it dissociates and is then hungry for CO2 again.
Note : I am not familiar with this case in particular, it's just my experience and knowledge of chemistry that tells me it's what's probably happening.

12:45 "We call these Clinkers. Honestly I have no idea why we call them Clinkers"

Clinker bricks are clay bricks that are too close to the heat source in the kiln. They come out overcooked, a darker color and usually misshapen and made a metallic ringing sound when you 'clinked' them together. They were rejects and discarded until their use was popularized during the Arts and Crafts architecture movement. Modern kilns are able distribute their heat more efficiently so they don't produce clinkers in the same way, but you can still buy bricks that are molded to give that misshapen and fire glazed look.

I cringed a bit when you said "filtered by reverse osmosis". We in the membrane community usually refers to filtration as anything mechanically separated, ultrafiltration is the cutoff for mechanical filtration, anything with smaller pores/molecular void spaces like nanofiltration and osmotic processes we call membrane separation. It can be a bit confusing since "nanofiltration" has the word filter in the name.

To preface this I don't work on a submarine but I have ran amine units.  Usually the exchanger to heat up the rich amine before the stripper is exchanging heat with the hot lean amine to cool it before meeting up with the gas, in this case the air.  Lean amine usually works best when its somewhere around 15 degrees warmer than the gas it is coming into contact with.

So "klinker" is a blacksmithing and heating term for the glassy slag left over while burning coal, it's a hard slag inclusion independent from the ash that needs to be broken and cleared to prevent it from blocking teh airflow.  Most coal burning devices have a "klinker breaker" to, obviously, break the klinker into pieces so it can fall through the grate.

Ahhhh, Amine. That smell just isn't right the first time you experience it, but you get used to it pretty quick. It is funny to watch how spouses react to that smell the first time their sailor returns from a sea jaunty. Whenever we deployed , we would keep our civilian clothes inside of vacuum sealed bags to keep them from smelling like Amine. Made our port trips to the bars much better. We also had the added benefits of conserving space in our bunk racks (since the vacuum sealing of the bags compressed the clothes) AND our clothes didn't get all wrinkled up. All told, knowing how vitally important Amine was to our survival, we were more than happy to absorb that smell for the sake of our safety. :)  Great video Destin. I love this series because it takes me back to my days onboard my sub.

I got a good chuckle when he said the oxygen generator was "down." I spent 3 years on a boat and not once did we ever operate that piece of equipment. It's nickname was "the bomb" due to the fact that it generates hydrogen gas and can be extremely dangerous. When we went on mission and would stay underwater most of the time, we'd just load up on oxygen candles and burn them as necessary. It was not uncommon for oxygen to drop to around 17%, which makes you constantly tired no matter how much sleep you've gotten.

The other thing is that clean, potable water is at a premium on a submarine. Our distiller could provide 10k gallons per day (if the operator knows what they're doing, if they weren't very proficient then significantly less). That's for the entire boat: drinking, washing dishes, laundry, showers, etc. We'd have to constantly remind people to limit their water use so that we didn't run out. It would make little sense to waste water on making oxygen when you can just burn a candle.

Oh, and amine? It gets everywhere. Go up to any AC vent in the engineroom and you'll notice a slight drip of an oily substance. That's amine. It will funk your clothes up for weeks after, even with repeated washing.

Cool! So the only consumables we need to breathe outside of Earth's atmosphere, besides equipment, are water and electricity/energy. Water can give us oxygen and hydrogen (which can be used as fuel to generate more power), MEA equipment can continuously remove carbon dioxide as long as it's powered. And there are unpowered chemical backups that can be held in storage for emergencies or if machines break down and need repairs.

Add nutrients for plant life that can be recycled from waste, and you'll also have the basic materials needed to farm crops and live indefinitely if you have the right equipment and can maintain it. With these clever technologies, with common basic elements consumed by the right machines humanity could settle outer space! Water is abundant and so are sources of energy: nuclear, solar, and often heat and wind. Submarines are pioneering artificial atmosphere technology!

One thing that has always had me wondering is how do they replenish the "nitrogen" in the atmosphere of the ship?

Sure, you can make oxygen by electrolysis and scrub out some of the carbon dioxide but nitrogen is the biggest fraction of our atmosphere at around 78%. You can't stay down constantly and just replenish oxygen. I assume there is some outgassing somewhere in the system and the nitrogen content would go down and the oxygen content would go up until you have flash-fires.

You would also build up some other more rare components of the metabolic processes of people (methane, ethane and a dozen or so others that I have forgotten). Periodically you need to snorkel and do an air exchange to purge those out.

The preheater on the CO2 scrubber is probably just a heat exchanger with the returning lean MEA as this will be hot from the boiler and will probably need to be cooled for it to absorb CO2 and also not significantly heat the air passing through the absorber.  Rather than have a separate cooler transferring as much of this heat to the rich MEA before it enters the boiler will make the whole process a lot more efficient.  This would be my best guess given the process you show and my experience with heat engines.

Heat of absorption of CO2 and partial pressure of CO2 with aqueous solutions of MEA has been measured in a reaction calorimeter CPA122 at 40, 80, and 120 oC for 30 wt% MEA solution and at 120 oC for 10 and 70 wt % MEA solutions. Heat of absorption measured in this work is also differential in loading, i.e. CO2 has been added to the reactor in steps. An experimental set-up used by Kim and Svendsen (2007) has been used in this work after a small modification. Experiments show that heat of absorption depends both on loading and temperature, though the temperature dependency is not as high as was reported earlier.

Some bricks are also called 'clinker' bricks because of the porous appearance of them.

R134a can also be detected by using the blue flame of propane and waving it around until it comes in contact with R134a (Tetrafluoroethane) or R-12 (dichlorodifluoromethane) when the Blue flame will turn brilliant green. The intensity of the greenness in the flame depends on the saturation level, so one can narrow the search for the source of the leak down by sweeping the area with the flame at floor level. This is not done in submarines for obvious reasons so they use a "Sniffer" instead. But, if you ever need to find a leak of these and some other nonvolatile gasses this is a good way to do so, with due "caution" of course.

The amine absorbs CO2 better when cold, so after the amine gets heated up in the boiler and had its CO2 driven off, first the now lean amine is used to preheat the incoming rich amine in a heat exchanger.This helps to cool the lean amine as well as pre-heat the rich amine, which reduces the amount of external heating and cooling that needs to be done, saving energy. The lean anime is then further cooled before being sprayed again.

Hi Destin, love your videos, I learn so much from them everyday. I’d like to answer why they use a preheater in the MEA column. (Chemical engineer here). Absorbing CO2 by MEA is a reversible reaction with an equilibrium. MEA holds CO2 only at lower temperatures, heating it up releases it as it does in the stripper which is a pressurized boiler. This produces lean MEA, but hot lean MEA cannot absorb CO2. To shift the equilibrium back in favor of absorbing CO2, we have to cool it. So why use energy to heat the MEA and then energy to cool it back down? Instead use the hot lean MEA exiting the stripper to heat the cold rich MEA entering the stripper. Viola, you solved the cooling and heating energy requirements (this is not 100% efficient ofcourse but you’re saving huge here). This is called heat integration (heat recovery) Remember the submariner said there’s a heat exchanger (HEX). The preheater you didn’t understand the purpose of is this HEX. Hope you learnt something today as did I. Cheers

The chlorate candle is exactly how they make supplemental oxygen for passenger in airliner in case of an emergency depressurization. And mishandling of those candle have actually brought down a passenger airliner, when some expired candles were ignited in the cargo hold, which did not have active fire suppression, but relied on being airtight to starve any fires of oxygen. However since the candles were generating oxygen, the fire kept burning and burning so hot that it burned through the cargo hold into and cabin as well as burning through vital components like control cables

Anyway, the term clinker is very old. comes from the days of coal fired furnaces and stoves. A clinker is basically a rock that looked like coal going in, but is just a rock and won't burn. what coal was on it or in it is burnt off, but the rock is still there. Nobody seems to know when or where the term was coined, but that's what it meant originally. More or less still does I see.

He didn't explain not ALL class D(delta) fires produce their own oxidizer (class D fires are usually caused by alkali metals such as potassium, magnesium, aluminum, and sodium) ignite at an extremely high temperatures or when exposed to water. Many can be extinguished with a dry chemical fire extinguisher or foam agent. However ⚠️SODIUM CHLORATE⚠️ is very powerful oxidizing agent and the combustion is practically impossible to extinguish. Small Sodium Chlorate flares used by scuba divers burn underwater without fail for light or signalling. When ignited the Sodium Chlorate smolders at a CONTROLLED 600°C (1,112°F), uncontrolled the crew wouldn't survive! Never open that containment case prematurely, just leave it alone! The CO & XO better not let anybody except Petty Officer Watson touch those candles.
On 21 March 21st 2007 aboard the UK Royal Navy HMS Tireless (S88) submarine, a Sodium Chlorate candle had become contaminated with hydraulic oil and exploded instantly, killing 2 sailors⚠️☠️😥😳

As a blacksmith, I can tell you that clinker comes from the byproduct of burning coal in a forge, which is the silica that melted out of the coal and solidified at the bottom of the firepot. It is basically worthless, but historically smiths would use it as paving material in front of their shops to keep the dust down. It is called clinker because it makes a clinking sound when you throw it on the ground.

I'm pretty sure that the preheating that he was referring to is done by a heat exchanger between the hot lean amine and the cooler rich amine. In your diagram you would run the amine output pipe of the lean mea around the rich mea output. Not only does it use waste heat to preheat the rich mea to save power, but it cools the lean mea output to promote absorption.

The 'pre-heat' is actually a heat exchanger, taking the hot co2 air and bringing it close to the MEA (like a reverse radiator) warming it up to make the boiler more effective and consume less power. Edit: it's possible that it uses the boiled lean MEA, but I think that would be counter intuitive, since hot particles bond better than cold ones (like trying to dissolve sugar in cold vs warm water) it also means that the rich MEA would be cooler before it goes into the heat exchanger making it less effective.

clinker is the stony residue from burnt coal or from a furnace.

The preheating of the rich MEA from the absorber to the the stripper - reboiler is often done by using the rich amine to cool the lean coming off the top of the stripper. The lean amine has to be cooled to increase the amount of CO2 it will absorb, (absorb at cool temperatures and generally high pressure, desorb at high temperatures and low pressure). The preheater is there to reduce the heat load on the reboiler and the lean amine cooler.
Oxygen candle is the same idea as the emergency oxygen generators on some aircraft, used when the cabin pressure drops too low.

the preheating function, is when they pass the lean amine which flows from the boiler-stripper through a heat exchanger, in which the hot, lean amine going to the absorber tower,  flows past,(but not mixes with) the rich amine coming from the absorber tower, thus recuperating the heat and feeding the heat back to the boiler-stripper. also, cooling the lean amine down so that it can take up CO2 in the absorber tower.   you probably know it, just not realised it yet :) there are similar heat exchangers in refrigerators, where the refrigerant goes in and out of the cold section.

Cement clinker is a solid material produced in the manufacture of Portland cement as an intermediary product. Clinker occurs as lumps or nodules, usually 3 millimetres (0.12 in) to 25 millimetres (0.98 in) in diameter. It is produced by sintering (fusing together without melting to the point of liquefaction) limestone and aluminosilicate materials such as clay during the cement kiln stage.Clinker occurs as lumps or nodules, usually 3 millimetres (0.12 in) to 25 millimetres (0.98 in) in diameter. It is produced by sintering (fusing together without melting to the point of liquefaction) limestone and aluminosilicate materials such as clay during the cement kiln stage.

The Clinker in an oxygen candle is much the same, only made with Iron (Fe), Sodium Chlorate and Barium Peroxide converting into Oxygen and Sodium Chloride (salt). The active ingredient is the Sodium Chlorate and the intense heat created by burning iron powder (600C or 1112F) causes thermal decomposition of the Chlorate. The burning iron is fed by the Chlorate decomposition, so although it is a fire which consumes oxygen to generate the heat, more oxygen is made than is consumes. The danger is that such an intense heat and abundance of oxygen can cause other materials to combust and it is tremendously important on a submarine that lubricants do not get into the candle as these may react explosively with the oxygen.

We use MEA and DEA in gas processing for CO2 and/or H2S removal. What they call a boiler we call a reboiler. We use stripper reflux (condensed water from the overhead the stripper) to cut amine losses. The rich lean exchanger is used to put heat back into the system. It's interesting that they use an amine system on a sub.

@SmarterEveryDay
Destin, as a US Submarine Veteran, I appreciate you taking the time out to make these videos. During my time on the USS Pennsylvania SSBN 735, one of my duties was standing the Auxiliary Electrician Forward watch. I became very familiar with CAMS MKII, and how to create O2 from electrolysis and burning of chlorate candles. Oftentimes, I would make recommendations to the OOD to increase the amperage of the EOGs in order to make higher concentrations of O2. Generally, we like to have the O2 around 18.5%...just enough to be up and doing things, but also low enough so those who wanted to sleep could sleep. Again, thank you for these videos. I haven't been on a submarine since 2010, and these videos help take me back... feeling nostalgic. 🇺🇸

Sniffers are big in the automotive industry also. You first check for visual leaks with dye in the system which glows like a light stick when shining a uv light on it, if you can't see any visible leaks or don't have access to a position to check ( like behind the dash ), obviously it's a lot of work to pull a whole dash out to check the the evaporator. So the next best thing for diagnostics is sniffers, move it around like a wand, and when it detects the gas it beeps at you. You then can compare it to different locations you can't access and if it only buzzed in one certain location then you can begin the repairs and start to pull things apart. They are a handy tool

Hey Destin, know you probably won’t see this, but as a steam fan preheating makes sense to me. I’ll use water as an example.

If you take, say water in Alaska in the winter and try to boil it from... I’ll say 33 degrees it’s gonna take a good while and it’s going to use up a larger amount of whatever fuel source you’re using to hear said water as opposed to if you preheated it to a non boiling state.
Steam engines can use this by running pipes directly next to the boiler to heat up the water somewhat before it actually enters, as heat is wasted energy. So running pipes from the tender, across the firebox, and against the boiler to the injection area(same problem as the water pressure problem for the sub), You’ll sop up some of the wasted heat in the incoming water, which allows it to become steam faster as its already warmer than it would have been.

The water can be used in the electrolyser, leaving methane.

I'm a chemical engineer working for a company that develops a simulation tool that simulates this type of CO2 removal process. The general process is call "amine gas treating" and is a fairly old process used to remove unwanted components (specifically hydrogen sulphide, or H2S, and carbon dioxide, or CO2) from process gas streams. Our company is really more geared towards simulating this process for industrial chemical plant scale equipment (refineries and gas plants) but the general process is basically the same as what they're using onboard that sub.

The exchanger is a lean/rich exchanger that exchanges thermal energy from the hot lean amine to the cooler rich amine. This serves two purposes: 1. to off load some of the thermal duty from the boiler (so you don't have to input as much energy) and 2. to cool down the lean amine before it returns to the absorber. Amine absorbs more efficiently at cooler temperatures. Absorbers are also typically run at higher pressures, but since they're sucking air in from the "atmosphere" it wouldn't really make much sense to compress that. That's also why they spray instead of using some sort of internal component (such as packing) since these internals increase the pressure drop through the tower and if you're already at atmospheric pressure you can't really accept much pressure drop at all. Internals would dramatically increase the available surface area available for the absorption process to take place since this process (or the rate at which the CO2 can be absorbed into the liquid) is governed by mass transfer.

Honestly after trying to explain this in a comment, just google "amine based carbon capture" and you'll probably come up with a much more comprehensive explanation or article. Who knows, you might even come across one i've coauthored :).

the main takeaway of this video is that you have a 2-level redundancy for both creating O2 and scrubbing CO2, one active and one passive. That way if the active method, which is primary because it is essentially infinite as long as you have power, fails the passive backup can be used, but only for a limited time because it will be used up. A quick insight on the one part of the amine stripper you said you weren't clear on, and that's the preheating. In my university researcher days, we were designing an amine stripper for bio gas (from dairy cow waste) to make transportation fuel. There's a cool video idea in there somewhere for ya, and feel free to reach out if you're curious about it.

The preheating of the amine is done using a heat exchanger as he said. What they're doing is rejecting heat from the hot newly lean amine into the cold rich amine, basically conserving the energy and lowering the heat load needed to boil it. Pretty simple really, he just didn't explain it super well. Typically this is done using a plate heat exchanger, and that appears to be what they're using there as well. So in your animation, between the pump and the tower that pipe would go to a heat exchanger with the pipe on the bottom.

One would think there could be a way to remove the carbon from the CO2, because there's a whole O2 molecule being wasted pumping it out to sea, and carbon would be more compact to store and dispose of.

With Amines in particular, there are 3 major types that are used, MEA I believe performs the best, but then there is always DEA, DGA and MDEA. In refineries, the latter is used more often (perhaps due to costs or something else). From my understanding, preheating helps increase the vapor pressure, which when it goes into the boiler, helps the regeneration process. If I am wrong, please do correct me.

23:37 I tried looking into the function of the preheating before the boiler stripper and here is what I understood from looking at two papers I'm way to stupid to fully understand: It's not so much that there's a heating element to heat the rich MEA before it goes into the boiler stripper, it's that there is a heat exchange thingmajig between the (cold) rich MEA going into the boiler stripper and the (hot) lean MEA coming out of the boiler stripper. Basically, the boiler spends all this energy to bring the MEA to a boil, and then you have to spend even more energy to cool the lean MEA down again before you can introduce it back into the absorber tower. The heat exchange is there to make the whole process much more energy efficient.

Abbreviated explanation: They use 2 methods

1) purified water and electrolysis to produce hydrogen and oxygen with potassium hydroxide as a catalyst - doing electrolysis on sea water produces chlorine gas and hydrogen.

2) burning iron and sodium chlorate. This produces Fe2O3, but the heat causes the NaClO3 which produces NaCl + O2. This is more of an emergency system in case electrolysis is unavailable.

Co2 is removed from the air by using monoethanolamine (MEA) to absorb it. Once it's absorbed teh MEA is heated to boil out the Co2.

When I worked in the coal mines we had lithium hydroxide canisters in our rescue chambers. Those were steel boxes that had an inflatable tent that you would roll out and it would fill up automatically via compressed air. You would then pull out the scrubber box and you would place 6 lithium hydroxide canisters on it and turn it on. You could adjust it to how many people were in it up to I believe 23 people for 48 hrs. It would change from a white color to a blueish color. Even if the allotted time for the canisters was up, you could still break them open and sprinkle them around. The tents themselves ranged anywhere from 30 ft to 50ft, depending on the manufacturer. The ones in the mines I worked at were 30ft.

Loved the video. The preheat step mentioned in 23:37 in an energy conservation technique wherein the hot lean amine exchanges heat with the incoming (stream to the stripper) cold rich amine. This allows to raise the temperature of the incoming rich amine to the stripper by exchanging heat from the hot lean amine going out. Result of all this jugglery, is to reduce the energy consumed to heat the cold rich amine. Moreover, the absorption is better at lower temperature hence, reducing the temperature of the hot lean amine promotes better absorption.

The reason for using a preheat unit is a very cleaver way to increase lean MEA CO2 absorbing efficiency, while conserving overall energy requirement of the system. The preheat is actually a heat exchanger. The heated MEA must be cooled down before being sprayed at the absorbing tower in order to properly absorb CO2. A good  way to loose all this heat, is to transfer it to the Rich MEA, before entering at the boiler, where it needs to be heated anyway. That's why This system have a preheat unit. This kind of design became much more energy efficient too.

the "Pre-heating" step is just an energy saving method. They take excess heat from the lean amine going back to the beginning of the process and use that to help heat the amine being sent to the boil-stripper. It helps the amine be at the right temperature for both parts of the process, relatively cool for trapping Co2, and really freaking hot for releasing it.

The "pre-heater" mentioned in the anime loop is actually a rich/lean amine heat exchanger. The hot lean amine gives up it's heat to the incoming cooler rich amine before the lean amine is fed to the absorber. Doing so provides couple benefits:
1. Pre-heats the incoming rich amine so less heat is needed to be supplied to the stripper. Makes the overall system more heat efficient.
2. Cooler amine can hold more CO2. Think how heating the rich amine liberates CO2 in the stripper. Increasing temperature of a liquid reduces gas solubility per Henry's Law.

"Clinkers" are descendants from the early 20th century, when most people used coal for heat.  Coal is mostly carbon and substances that are vaporized when heated. As much as 5% of the mass of coal is not burned or vaporized. These substances form solid remnants that had to be cleaned out of furnaces.  The sound each one made when shoveled into wheelbarrows was "clink".

The heat exchanger / preheat is a heat exchanger that heats the rich amine with the lean amine coming out of the boiler. The stripping tower needs to be cool to absorb the CO2. comment_by: Chris Garcia,  Host of - Is It Just Speculation?
comment_text: This video makes me appreciate the engineering AND Navy more than anything I've ever seen. Everyone is so well trained on every aspect of their job and the ship.

We build amine plants to strip naturally occurring CO2 from natural gas wells all the time. The exchanger between the pump and the boiler is cross exchanging the hot, lean amine (coming from the boiler) with the cool, rich amine. It essentially pre-heats the rich amine with the extra energy from the now lean amine, recycling a bit of heat and saving some energy. But in the gas business the contactors and regeneration stills are each 30-40 feet tall and several feet in diameter. Even accounting for the lower volume of gas being treated, the miniaturization required to get the whole thing onto a submarine (and into a single compartment?!) is impressive.

In the boiler, the R-MEA is heated, and this heating allows it to separate CO2 from it. This happens because the solubility of MEA (towards CO2) decreases with an increase in temperature. Once stripped of the CO2, the MEA needs to be cooled down so that its solubility can be increased again. So instead of using a cooler, they use a heat exchanger that cools down the L-MEA stream (boiler outlet) and pre-heats the R-MEA stream (boiler inlet). Thus saving some energy.

A "clinker" is also the name of a lava flow where the cooled lava pieces fall down the side of the volcano and make a very distinct "clinking" sound similar to the sound all the broken tempered glass window pieces make when they fall onto concrete. "Clinker" lava rocks are very porous like a sponge or a coral reef, and look very similar to those used candles. I assumed the used candles were referred to as "clinkers" because of the similarity in appearance to clinker lava rocks.

There actually is another way to make air from water...Boil it! When water begins to boil, those bubbles are mostly air dissolved in the water. When it reaches a fuller boiling stage, that is pure water vapor. So boiling seawater in its earlier stages would release air dissolved in the water, and then it could be discharged when it reaches depletion. But boiling need not be hot. It can be simply put in a vacuum chamber and the air pumped out into the submarine until the initial room temperature boiling has depleted the air in the water. I gets pumped out and new water brought in to get more.

Clinker is the term for solid fuel impurities left behind after high temperature combustion. When you burn a solid fuel (which is essentially what the candles are) all of the non-combustible impurities left behind melt together and solidify. This is extremely common in blacksmithing and industrial smelting. The word clinker comes from the Dutch "Klinker" and originally referred to vitrified bricks before being used to refer to any vitrified residue or dross.

Historical nerd fact. In the age of the steam ship, clinkers from the coal burners were dumped overboard during the journey, leaving paths on the ocean floor that historians can use to follow the most commonly used routes across the Atlantic.

The MEA CO2 cycle also has a condenser step between the boiler/stripper and the spray tank. The condenser needs to lose heat to condense the MEA. That's where the pre-heater comes in.  A heater exchanger takes heat away from the condenser and uses it to heat the MEA going into the boiler. This not only saves energy, but also reduces the size of the boiler.

The heat exchanger is probably flowing the hot lean MEA from the boiler past the cold rich MEA in from the absorber tower, a counterflow heat exchanger. That way you cool the hot MEA and heat the cold MEA at the same time and save some energy.
Another Great Video, Thanks VERY MUCH!!

I worked at a natural gas cryo facility (the primary purpose of which was to separate LNGs like ethane and propane from the "dry" methane) that used a very similar rich/lean amine process to pull CO2 from the gas. I believe our system bubbled the gas up through the amine, rather than spraying amine on top of it.

That preheat function you said you didn't understand is most likely (based on my experience with our system) just a heat exchanger where the hot lean amine they just removed CO2 from runs by the cooler rich amine (there are a bunch of different methods but ultimately they're trying to maximize surface area contact, either through separate plates, a series of tubes, or some other method). They never mix, they're just trying to move heat from the lean amine to the rich amine. This serves a dual purpose. First, they're "pre-heating" the rich amine so they use less energy to heat it and boil off the CO2 later. Second, they're cooling the lean amine. As you know, the cooler the lean amine is, the more CO2 it can absorb. They may have to cool it further (I suspect they do), but that helps the process along.

For us, the preheater saved us burning some of our sellable product (methane) for heating. They'll be achieving a similar goal of energy savings, though not profit motivated.

Clinkers: when things burn, there are two by products: Ash and Clinkers. Ash is the powdery stuff we all know and hate. Clinkers are rock-like objects. The term comes from the days of coal-fired blacksmiths. Underneath their burning coal, there is a bucket that collects the solid waste. Ash falls silently. The left over rocks clink as they hit the metal bucket. Those things, after burning, are quite large clinkers.

Former Amine plant operator here.  The heat exchanger transfers heat from the just boiled lean amine and adds it to the incoming rich amine.  Cooled amine can hold more CO2, the heat exchanger helps CO2 scrubbing effectiveness by slightly cooling the lean and heating the rich.  That heat exchange also reduces the amount of energy the system requires to boil the rich amine by using the waste heat lost by the lean amine to preheat the rich amine before boiling.  Not submarine related, but our plant stripped CO2 out of natural gas using MEA and MDEA.

For those who are unaware, I’ll explain the preheating process.
The MEA must not be hot in order to absorb CO2. And must be hot to release the CO2. Raising a substance from not hot to hot takes a lot of energy. A preheater increases efficiency by utilizing waste heat. Excess heat that would otherwise just be dumped overboard is instead redirected to processes like this. The waste heat is not enough to raise the MEA to CO2 loss temperature, but it does raise the temperature so the boiler has to do less work, which means the boiler uses less energy. It is not critical to the process, just increases efficiency.

Minor correction: The potassium hydroxide does not act as a catalyst. It is only there to make the water conductive . That's it. Pure water is actually a poor conductor of electricity and electrolysis is an electric circuit. So you just have to add something, anything, that makes it conductive. A catalyst - which this is not - would play a chemical role where it bonds to multiple stages of chemicals and lowers the energy to make them convert, but that does not happen here in any way. It only plays an electrical role. The chemistry of the ion doesn't actually matter. You can use table salt (bad, as it releases some chlorine gas, as you showed), baking soda, TSP (stuff you wash walls with), battery acid, just about anything conductive. The selection of Potassium Hydroxide as the electrolyte has to do with it being slightly better than the plethora of other electrolytes in terms of having minimal other side-reactions, not being corrosive, not bonding to the electrodes, etc, but it's not that big of a deal, and it's not highly-selected for it's unique properties the way a chemical catalyst would be.

There's an excellent book on nuke subs called The Rickover Effect.  One section covered the issues with air quality on the Nautilus, mainly the scrubbers were malfunctioning and leaking MEA, which is somewhat toxic.  That led to high CO2 levels in the sub.  Plus, refrigerant contamination was high, causing throat irritation.  Naval Reactors couldn't do anything about it because those systems were handled by the Bureau of Ships.  So, several engineers traveled to DC to plead the case for better air quality on the Nautilus with the head doctor at BuShips.  The doctor mused that he had a friend who served in the sub core in WW2 and said they had to surface every night to charge the batteries and used that opportunity to exchange the air, adding "it worked quite well"  The lead engineer stood up and said "we did not design a propulsion system that allows a sub to stay submerged indefinitely only to have it need to surface regularly for fresh air!"

Once again, Destin highlights systems aboard one of the most complex mechanisms ever created: A nuclear-powered submarine. O2 generation and CO2 scrubbing are two of the most critical of those systems. These non-propulsion, or auxiliary, systems are maintained by Auxiliary Machinist's Mates, or MM(A).

Two important things Destin's not covered yet are qualification and cross-training. Within a set period of time after reporting for duty, each and every person serving aboard a submarine must a) qualify on systems and watches pertaining to their specialization, as well as b) qualify on all critical systems. This latter achievement is what earns a submariner his/her dolphins.

In order to do so, all non-nuclear personnel must successfully complete watches and pass examinations in areas outside of their area of specialization, with the exception of anything nuclear. For nuclear personnel, they must do the same, in addition to successfully standing watches and passing examinations in mechanical, electrical and reactor operations.

All nuclear personnel are cross-trained in all disciplines, while non-nuclear personnel are cross-trained in all non-nuclear disciplines.

So, if you're impressed by the knowledge and professionalism of service members such as petty officers Dow, Watson and Palmer, consider that these sailors can be as young as 18 or 19 and have successfully completed basic training, the fundamental training for their area of specialization and submarine school. For nuclear sailors, add nuke school, prototype and, optionally, ELT training, to everything before.

These sailors are a testament to the Navy's excellent selection criteria and training, and are truly among the best in the Navy and any service.

I don't think they use reverse osmosis on subs.  At least they didn't when I served in the 90's.  The engine room has a steam plant powered evaporator that makes many thousands of gallons of fresh water a day.  This is sufficiently demineralized to feed the steam plant's makeup water needs.  Then you just need to run this demineralized water through a resin bed to make it pure enough for the electrolytic oxygen generator.  The only electric power needed is for the o2 generator itself.

I have a background in Chemical Engineering, so the absorber/stripper process is all too familiar. I would guess the heat exchanger before the boiler is a way to recuperate energy from the spent lean amine. If you spend a lot of energy heating up the rich amine, forcing the CO2 out of solution and making it ‘lean’,  you might as well recover that energy and reduce your overall boiler duty. You get the additional benefit of helping cooler your lean amine.

Dude... is not that complicated to understand the concept of reverse osmosis. Basically, osmosis is the tendency of pure water to move through a permeable membrane to the other side, where salts and other solubles are concentrated. the water wants to balance both sides' concentration.
Reverse osmosis is getting pure water out of the concentrated section of the membrane by increasing the pressure with a pump to beat the natural osmotic pressure. you press the concentrated solution against the membrane and force the water molecules through, as the solubles are not able to go through, resulting in permeated water or "purified water". Different types of permeable membranes exist that result in different levels of purification of the resulting water.

Clinkers is an old term from the middle ages back when blacksmiths used coal coke to forge iron. When coke burns out completely the impurities in the material condense into glass-like lumps called "clinkers". These clinkers need to be removed because they suck the heat out of the forge and make forging more difficult.

The heat exchange would pass the hot lean Amine by the cooler rich amine separated by a highly thermo conductive material as either are traveling to their respective destinations. This way some of the heat from the lean Amine is leeched into the passing rich Amine requiring less energy to boil it.

Heat exchanges often separate the fluid into many small channels that interweave to increase the surface area of the exposure

Hey Destin, @24:20 you show some turbo pumps working. Technically you should flip the rotors (impellers) to make it work.
(also: the ingress is on the axis and the egress is on the edge, so e.g. on the bottom pump don't make the ingress tangential to the housing of the pump, rather make it perpendicular, right through the middle.)
I remember from my prof back in the day: at least the rotation should be correct – he was quite adamant about that. :-)
Note 2: forward-bended rotors do exist and are used, but not in systems like these – think: low pressure, slow rotation ventilation systems where low noise production is key.

@SmarterEveryDay The "pre heating you did not get" is heat exchanger. On one side you have (in this case) the cold MEA that needs to be heated and on the other side you have hot MEA that needs to be cooled... so instead of wasting energy on heating and cooling you let the hot MEA warm the cold MEA on its way to the boiler and in exchange the hot MEA is being cooled on its way to the scrubber.

Based on your description of the CO2 scrubber system, the 'pre-heater' is likely a heat exchanger. After the CO2 is released from the heated MEA, the hot MEA is passed through a heat exchanger to preheat the incoming CO2 rich MEA solution.

This reduces the amount of heat you have to dump somewhere else and reduces the energy required heat up the MEA and remove the CO2.

Source: A good chunk of my PhD dissertation.

I'm not sure if most people can appreciate how dangerous these chemicals are that the submarine systems use. It's good to see that the submariners treat their jobs very seriously. Those candles create an excess of O2 which means the reaction can get out of control but I suspect it doesn't because they limit the contact of the O2 and iron. The MEA is a very strong base, but it is also an organic chemical which means it can be easily absorbed into human tissue, it's flammable and volatile. An MEA leak in sufficient amounts would absorbed through a person's lungs and kill the tissue in your lungs quickly, unless of course an explosion killed you first. Both of these chemical reactions in the sub's systems are very dangerous, but under the right conditions they're controlled carefully. It's fascinating! Thanks for putting this on.

@SmarterEveryDay That heat exchanger on the CO2 scrubber is likely used to reduce energy consumption in the boiler stripper unit. That heat exchanger is probably set up as a feed-effluent heat exchanger where hot MEA leaving the boiler is used to preheat the feed to the boiler. This thereby cools the stream entering the absorber (MEA has higher CO2 solubility at low temps) and warms the stream entering the boiler, reducing how much additional heat is required to reach the boiling point. These are super common in chemical plants to reduce energy costs.

At 23:38 the preheat is probably from a Lean/Rich Amine Heat Exchanger. The Rich Amine will pass on the tube side and the Lean Amine will pass on the shell side. The hot Lean Amine will preheat the Rich Amine reducing the load on the boiler. Vice versa, the cooler Rich amine cools the Lean Amine at the same time. At least that's what we do at our LNG plant to be more efficient.

23:37 about the preheating. I've worked with MEA CO2-absorbers on much larger scale for biogas purification, the same are also used for natural gas. The preheating is there done with a heat exchanger where the hot lean MEA coming from the stripper meets the cool rich MEA from the absorber. This both saves energy for heating plus you want the lean MEA to be cool so it absorbs CO2 better. But I've never heard anyone pronounce it amine lika Amy. It's chemically related to amino acids so I say the a in amine like amino acid or ammunition.

Edit: 21:25 about the boiler/stripper having high(er) pressure. The stripper shall have relatively low pressure since that promotes gases to leave the liquid. Some strippers are run at vacuum to make the boiling at lower temperature (a little less than 100 °C) but most common is around 1 atm. It would surprise me if the stripper has any significant over pressure since that would require higher temperature and also breaks down the MEA faster.

Fun fact: the sensation of asphyxiation is caused by the rising CO2 in the blood, aka rising acidity which is what is detected by our body. In other words our body can only really know if there is too much CO2 but not really if there is enough Oxygen.
This has the implication that as long as you are correctly expelling CO2 your body will tell you everything is fine even if you aren't actually breathing Oxygen, until you just die like a light switch has been flipped.

The further implication of this fact is that for once breathing just Nitrogen is the absolutely most painless way to die and would be the most humane way of euthanasia/execution.
And secondly that intelligent design goes out of the window right away because there are other animals that can in fact detect O2 levels directly, like naked mole rats, which means that a biological mean to do so exist and the "designer" just forgot about it when making us which you know makes the whole thing ridiculous (and there are many other examples of "design" flaws).

P.S.: Oxygen candles are the main emergency oxygen supplies in airplanes. The fact that you are instructed to decidedly pull on the tube for the oxygen to start flowing is because the candle above your head needs to be lit as the candles shown in the video.

12:54 clinkers? That's what blacksmiths call the slag and crud that you find in a coal forge. There is a part in the bottom of the firepot (the bowl where the coal sits) inside the air inlet called a "clinker-breaker"

Destin, the absorber/stripper is a common process in many industrial processes. My guess on the preheater is that it's just a simple heat exchanger. As the hot, lean amine is leaving the stripper, it is run through an exchanger where the other fluid is the cool rich amine that is entering the stripper. This increases the heating efficiency of the stripper by preheating the entering fluid, and I would guess also increases the efficiency of the absorber as I would guess the absorption capability of the amine is reduced at higher temperatures, so it's advantageous to cool the lean amine before entering the absorber.

" you can just open these Lithium Hydroxide canisters and sprinkle them on the bunks where they sleep..." UM... Im not sure that's the best Idea. I don't think you want to sprinkle that anywhere. Yes it can be used without power as a passive means of scrubbing oxygen, but you don't want that stuff getting anywhere close to our skin, and definitely don't want that stuff as a powder that can get into the air for people to breath in by accident, and that's not to mention what would happen if it comes into contact with water. You keep that stuff in its own filter box and plug it into a fan or circulation system, you don't sprinkle it around like it's road salt.

I think the key to understand the MEA scrubbing process is as Dow explained: the rich MEA us pumped to a PRESSURIZED tank to be boiled. It's like letting a can of coke sit out in the sun. Higher temp = reduced ability for CO2 to remain dissolved = the coke (or rich MEA in this case) goes flat. CO2 comes out to be dumped, and the MEA leaves behind to be reused; the pressurization, I'm assuming, is to keep the hot MEA in liquid state so it doesn't boil away along with the CO2. As for the pre-heating, I'm assuming that it's just to keep the warming of the rich MEA a bit more efficient.
